review_title: B&FC - A fantastic place to work
job_title: Head of Registry Services in Bispham, England
pros:
Colleagues are friendly and supportive, making new staff feel welcomed.
Senior management lead in a calm manner and making colleagues feel valued and most importantly never intrude on ones time when away from the office, this is most unique and extremely appreciated. 
Sufficient timescales are given to complete tasks
The accommodation/campus is first class.
B&FC offer excellent staff benefits (pay awards & health care to name just 2)
Excellent team spirit and camaraderie between colleagues
The students are in the main very well behaved
Tonnes of car parking space
cons: Due to being such a large organisation, some areas do their own thing, whether that be following a different process or creating a database or buying in some software that is not aligned with the IT strategy.

cons: A bit hierarchical but very supportive in Curriculum areas

review_title: Ridiculous workload, stagnent, push students through
pros:
Great annual leave 
Lovely teams of teaching staff but they are undervalued and not supported by senior management at all. 
Staff stay for the students because they really care.
cons:
Workload is really high
Lots of pressure to get students through and get students on course even if it's not right for them
Very Low pay 
Poor facilities (very dated)
Students aren't ready for masters when they graduate (lots can't cope at other institutions)
Little chance for development 
Zero research culture

review_title: A great place to work and thrive

cons: None observed as of yet.

review_title: Was once outstanding, sadly no longer
pros: Still some good staff working at the college who really do try to give there best to the students.
cons: Teaching has become secondary to administration and collecting data, no time for staff to prep outstanding lessons , unless you want to work all your weekends and evenings, quality in some areas has gone out the window long ago, it's now recruit as many students as you can, do your best to retain them on the course and get them through whatever that takes, no one can fail.

job_title: Business Development Officer in Bispham, England
pros: The College are a great employer with many different employee perks in place. I was poorly at the start of this year and the College, in particular, my line mgr were absolutely fantastic with me. I still need to go for regular reviews at the hospital now and nothing is ever a problem as far as the College are concerned. The people are great, the results are great and I can not be happier in my work place. Fantastic place to work with great HR systems in place
cons: There is nothing as far as my job role is concerned that I can see improvement for

review_title: Ofsted need to do their job
pros: If you’re lucky you’ll work with good people and won’t be bullied by managers
cons: All I can say for those people who are here to review B&FC.....do not study or work there. The negative reviews you see here are factual. Let’s face it, the detail is too specific to be sour grapes. The place is a shambles, at best it’s all fur coat and no knickers and at worst, well! All I can say is the negative reviews are accurate to the letter. Ambiguous results at best does not even scratch the surface. It’s all a numbers game. If Ofsted voted them outstanding again it’d be a miracle or a gross negligence.  Steet clear people. Staff there hate it and they’re miserable!

review_title: An interesting place to work but not quite ready to be a university
pros:
- Opportunity to teach a broad range of subjects
- Flexible working hours
- Very supportive of staff development (supportive of training, conferences, industrial visits and workshops)
- Freedom to create and deliver your own subject content as you see fit
- Friendly staff
- Small class sizes (typically <20)
- Focus on personal development and tutorials
- Some excellent teaching facilities and equipment
- Plenty of options on-site and near-by for food and drink
- Campuses are very well-located
cons:
- May be over-stretched on module topics and hours.
- Same teaching hours and salary scales for both FE and HE, which is independent of the type of qual and skill level required.
- May be asked to cover unfamiliar classes with no heads-up.
- HE salary is lower than university academia, and is lower than typical entry-level roles within industry.
- First pay increase (1%) may take 23 months to acquire if you join after September.
- They might surprise you with golden handcuffs (relocation up to £5k, teacher training £2k) for up to 3 years.
- Management game-playing, hoarding information, resisting change, rehearsing meetings with you, or otherwise censoring communication between lecturers and externals.
- Scarcity bonus is pre-tax, is never guaranteed, may stop at any point, and may take up to 2 years to acquire if at all.
- Lecturers are rarely incentivised, supported, or rewarded. The long-serving employees are generally more cynical.
- Plenty of under-skilled/under-experienced teaching staff in HE acquired from other departments, other industries/straight out of college.
- Budgets, bids, staffing, timetabling, programme developments all in the hands of management, not programme leaders.

pros: A handful of decent supportive staff. Nice when you make a difference to a student
cons: Friends getting promotions/positions. Some very challenging students that have had dozens of chances and shouldnt be on programme should either be in borstal or a mental health setting. Lots of backstabbing. Wages not increased for years. Bispham campus very dated in places. Slow internal systems.

pros: The staff are great. The management really invest a lot of time and money in training and preparing staff to do the best jobs possible. This allows us to provide the best possible service and care to every student, parent and business partner.
cons: New full-time / permanent contracts do not exist. This makes working there feel a bit insecure as you have no guarantee that you are needed each academic year.

review_title: Great Management and Chances for progression
pros:
The curriculum managers are fantastic
Values industry experience and expertise
Rewarding working with students who are from a deprived area and seeing their progress
Strong links with Lancaster University
cons: Lack of department research opportunities or time comparatively to other universities and colleges.

review_title: Bums on seats mentality whatever the consequences
pros: It is still supposedly outstanding. Wont be by the next inspection.
cons: Bums on seats. Students must pass, even though they have barely attended half the lessons.  Money is King. One student (although this happened many times) enrolled in September. Must've attended three classes from Sept-Dec. Came in for one lesson in January. I was told ' because the student has turned up in January, it's my fault if they fail'.

pros: It has a car park.
cons:
Unsupportive management.
It's a place where nepotism thrives and family/friends who are unqualified get jobs over qualified people.
They don't care what's going on in a students life as long as you get them to pass, by any means...
Even when you're a teacher with lots of experience you're still micro managed to point they want to know when you go to the toilet.
Food and drink is really expensive.
They constantly put more and more work on you until you break.
It's not a good atmosphere to work in.

pros: Some good people stay loyal to their local college
cons: Circus management change their minds all the time, Corporate bullies who see the students as £’s. They have wasted millions on failed developments that have not benefited the community and expect staff wages to suffer. It’s all about looking good in the management structure and climbing the ladder. Ousted need to look into the practice of everyone has to pass regardless of ability. They are failing the community and are very out of touch with its needs.

pros: The job is very rewarding. Colleagues are great.  Term time only so get to enjoy summer holidays with the kids.
cons: Due to a lack of funding,  people are losing hours / or not receiving their permanent contracts.
